name: Acceptable Encryption Policy
content:
# Acceptable Encryption Policy

**Consensus Policy Resource Community**

---

## üìù Free Use Disclaimer

This policy was created by or for the [SANS Institute](https://www.sans.org/) for the Internet community. All or parts of this policy can be freely used for your organization ‚Äî no prior approval is required.

To contribute a new or updated version of this policy, email: [policy-resources@sans.org](mailto:policy-resources@sans.org)

**Last Update Status:** June 2014

---

## 1. Overview

See section [2. Purpose](#2-purpose).

---

## 2. Purpose

This policy aims to:

- Limit the use of encryption to algorithms that have undergone substantial public review and proven effective.
- Ensure compliance with **Federal regulations** and that legal authority is granted for the dissemination and use of encryption technologies outside the United States.

---

## 3. Scope

This policy applies to **all \<Company Name\> employees and affiliates**.

---

## 4. Policy

### 4.1 Algorithm Requirements

- **4.1.1 Symmetric Encryption**  
  Ciphers in use must meet or exceed those defined as **"AES-compatible"** or **"partially AES-compatible"** per:
  - [IETF/IRTF Cipher Catalog](https://datatracker.ietf.org/)
  - [NIST FIPS 140-2](https://csrc.nist.gov/publications/detail/fips/140/2/final)
  - Superseding documents

  ‚úÖ Use of **Advanced Encryption Standard (AES)** is strongly recommended.

- **4.1.2 Asymmetric Encryption**  
  Algorithms must align with [FIPS 140-2](https://csrc.nist.gov/publications/detail/fips/140/2/final) or successor standards.

  ‚úÖ Use of **RSA** and **Elliptic Curve Cryptography (ECC)** is strongly recommended.

#### 4.1.3 Signature Algorithms

| Algorithm | Key Length (Min) | Additional Comment |
|----------|------------------|--------------------|
| ECDSA    | P-256            | Consider [RFC 6090](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6090) to avoid patent infringement |
| RSA      | 2048             | Use a secure padding scheme (e.g., PKCS#7). Message hashing is required. |
| LDWM     | SHA256           | Refer to **LDWM Hash-based Signatures Draft** (currently draft-only; see IRTF/Internet Drafts) |

---

### 4.2 Hash Function Requirements

In general, \<Company Name\> adheres to the [NIST Policy on Hash Functions](https://csrc.nist.gov/projects/hash-functions).

---

### 4.3 Key Agreement and Authentication

- **4.3.1** Use one of the following key exchange protocols:
  - [Diffie-Hellman (DH)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diffie%E2%80%93Hellman_key_exchange)
  - [Internet Key Exchange (IKE)](https://datatracker.ietf.org/wg/ipsec/about/)
  - [Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman (ECDH)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Elliptic-curve_Diffie‚ÄìHellman)

- **4.3.2** Authenticate endpoints prior to exchanging or deriving session keys.

- **4.3.3** Authenticate public keys before use:
  - Example: via cryptographically signed messages
  - Or: manual verification of public key hash

- **4.3.4** Authentication servers (e.g., RADIUS, TACACS) must have certificates signed by a trusted provider.

- **4.3.5** All applications and servers using **SSL/TLS** must use certificates signed by a trusted Certificate Authority (CA).

---

### 4.4 Key Generation

- **4.4.1** Keys must be securely generated and stored to prevent loss, theft, or compromise.

- **4.4.2** Key generation must use a standard [Random Number Generator (RNG)](https://csrc.nist.gov/publications/detail/sp/800-90a/rev-1/final), for example from:
  - [NIST Annex C: Approved RNGs for FIPS PUB 140-2](https://csrc.nist.gov/publications/detail/fips/140/2/final)

---

## 5. Policy Compliance

### 5.1 Compliance Measurement

The **Infosec Team** will verify policy compliance through:

- Business tool reports  
- Internal and external audits  
- Feedback to the policy owner  

### 5.2 Exceptions

Any exception to this policy must be pre-approved by the **Infosec Team**.

### 5.3 Non-Compliance

Violations may result in disciplinary action, up to and including **termination of employment**.

---

## 6. Related Standards, Policies, and Processes

- [NIST FIPS 140-2 Publication](https://csrc.nist.gov/publications/detail/fips/140/2/final)
- [NIST Policy on Hash Functions](https://csrc.nist.gov/projects/hash-functions)

---

## 7. Definitions and Terms

The following definitions and terms can be found in the [SANS Glossary of Terms](https://www.sans.org/security-resources/glossary-of-terms/):

- **Proprietary Encryption**
